column18:
I ranked funding as the highest need. As a new school, we are bound by budgets that really hamper us dreaming bigger. Correction...we dream big, just cannot afford all of our dreams.

I was also a little confused with the wording around accountability systems. I love data, it is what drives decisions. However, I believe we are measuring a lot of the wrong things in one shot assessments. I also wanted to include that graduation requirements actually hinder a lot of what we value as important. I have a teacher looking to 'ungrade' next year. This should be a lot of fun especially when educating parents about the reasoning.
column19: With a career/workforce focus, we depend on public service providers to speak, set up for showcases, provide volunteer & internship placements, serve on Advisory Boards, be present as time allows. column18: Support from our philanthropic partners and additional state funding has helped us to sustain our innovation work. column18:
The ones I listed high are ones that directly impact the services we can offer our students.  Revenue and interactions with public services allow us to give complete wrap around services to all of our students that are in need since we are an at-risk program for students that literally are on their last chance to get a diploma and the skills needed to be successful in life.

Accountability is huge and I support it, however, accountability looks completely different in a virtual school for at-risk youth.  That has to be taken into consideration as it is real.  Another piece around accountability is the fact, accountability must include student behavior when it comes to virtual learning.  We have a great system that I would love to share as it has been very successful for us.  Others need to see it and I would love to help people understand that.

Finally teacher credentials need to make sense as well as take into consideration the "real" world and situations we are living in.  There is a teacher shortage and adding more is only hurting the teacher pool to pick from.  Evaluations also need to make sense in a virtual setting.  Most evals are set up for traditional school, not virtual schools.
column19: We work with probation officers and local community agencies currently.  I would like to see those expanded to create a partnership and we can create specific services together for kids with mental health and other needs.

column18:
Calendar and schedule are, huge constraints on innovation. New programs, particularly those that are community-based, like ours, need space in the schedule that allows students to get out of the school building during the day and interact with other adults and projects. 
Another critical factor is the state-level and district-level support for Flexible Pathways and transferable skills instruction. These support new approaches against the inertia of existing systems.

column18: We are a public charter school that serves a diverse population.  If we were not a public school we would not have the capacity to raise enough money to run our school or our program.  That being said, we fundraise about $500,000 annually to cover our program's extra costs.  And our district has an open enrollment single system, which helps us to find and place families in our program.

column18: As a charter school network in Indiana, we do not have access to local property tax revenue. Traditional school districts use that locally generated revenue to support their facility needs and are able to keep all of the state per pupil funding for school operations. In our case, we have to use the per pupil funding for operations and for facilities. This means that maximizing public revenue and philanthropic dollars is critical to our continued operation and expansion. While we are exempt from seat time requirements, the lack of flexibility in the traditional K-12 management systems (SIS, LMS) makes us work harder to implement our unique model.

column18: As a public charter school in North Carolina, we are funded at 84% of a traditional public school. We are located in a Tier 1, high poverty region of NC, so there is very limited philanthropic funding available in our region. We would not have a school were it not for initial funding and grants from some of our historical partners. Also, we must have flexibility for seat time in order to be able to offer students the flexibility they need to be able to complete a 2-year degree and full local internship while they complete high school graduation requirements.

column18: Our school model can be best implemented in an environment where there is regulatory flexibility with regard to who gets to teach. column18: Our responses may be a little misleading. Flexibility in scheduling, graduation requirements, seat time, and course progressions is hugely important to us, and we have this due to our pursuit of state-level waivers and our policy advocacy to support legislation enabling our innovations. I rated them lower because they are no longer much a barrier. I rated public funding highest because we depend on it fully. Teacher credentialing and contractual HR relationships reduce our hiring flexibility pretty dramatically, sometimes not a big deal and at other times (like when district tries to displace staff to our school) a big problem.

column18: The Parker School is a charter school; charters in MA are funded quite leanly.  We need more robust funding to support team teaching and research-based student-teacher ratios. It is extremely difficult to keep this work alive, and share our innovations, without foundation funding.

column18: Public funding, which is historically inequitable for charter schools, is of utmost importance to our innovation work. Lower public funding means a higher need to secure philanthropic funds, which is driven by accountability/reporting requirements and student enrollment. Higher philanthropy needs means larger time and effort dedication of personnel to seek out funding, apply and manage reporting.

column18:
We are a school of choice district. Those flexible laws are essential to the financial health. The way public schools are funded in Michigan is essential not equitable. We receive the lowest foundation amounts from the state while other districts receive thousands more. Yet, communities in the lower FTE category typically have the highest need.  

Where we are in the continuum of personalized learning, some factors mentioned are not as much of an issue now but will be as we possibly move to more of a competency based approach. 

We do not typically receive philanthropic funding. 

Seat time flexibility laws are absolutely essential for us as we are an online/hybrid public school.

Another issue is that many of our family have zero respect for state mandated academic assessments.
